questions.text: 12B fracture according to AO classification means....
questions.solution:
1. indicates humerus
  2. indicates mid shaft

B indicates some comminution

questions.text: Which of the following fracture has the highest healing potential...?
questions.solution: Spiral fracture has the highest surface area, hence maximum healing potential.

questions.text: Causalgia is....
questions.solution:
CRPS type 2: causalgia, usually post nerve injury

All types of CRPS have a bad prognosis

questions.text: Swimmers view is to locate?
questions.solution: Cervical spine swimmer's lateral view is a modified lateral projection of the cervical spine to visualize the C7/T1 junction. As technology advances, computed tomography has replaced this projection, yet there remain many institutions (especially in rural areas) where computed tomography is not readily available.

choices.text: Due to injury to the FDP
Due to injury to lateral bands of extensor tendon

questions.text: Mallet finger, which statement is true:
questions.solution: Mallet finger is an injury to the thin tendon that straightens the end joint of a finger or thumb. Although it is also known as 'baseball finger', this injury can happen to anyone when an unyielding object (like a ball) strikes the tip of a finger or thumb and forces it to bend further than it is intended to go.

questions.text: MC complication of scaphoid fracture:
questions.solution:
Patients with a scaphoid malunion may have an acceleration of radiocarpal arthritis and significant wrist symptoms. Amadio et al reported that patients with a lateral intrascaphoid angle (LISA) >45° had satisfactory outcome in only 27% and posttraumatic arthritis in 54% of cases

Avascular necrosis (AVN) is a common complication of a scaphoid fracture. Since the scaphoid blood supply comes from two different vascular branches of the radial artery, fractures can limit access to blood supply. Risk of AVN depends on the location of the fracture.

questions.text: Which Type of scoring is used in classifying osteoporosis according to WHO?
questions.solution:
T score: comparison of BMD to young adult reference mean

Z score is for age, sex, race matched population.

questions.text: Following is true regarding X linked hypophosphatemia except:
questions.solution: As Serum Ca is normal, PTH usually normal.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in pagets disease:
questions.solution: Medications. Osteoporosis drugs (bisphosphonates) are the most common treatment for Paget's disease of bone. Bisphosphonates are typically given by injection into a vein, but they can also be taken by mouth. When taken orally, bisphosphonates are generally well tolerated but can irritate the stomach

questions.text: Pepper pot skull/salt and pepper appearance of skull is classic of.
questions.solution:
Salt and pepper sign or pepper pot skull refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria caused by resorption of trabecular bone in hyperparathyroidism. There is a loss of definition between the inner and outer tables of the skull and a ground-glass appearance as well as spotty deossification.

Hyperparathyroidism is the effect of excess parathyroid hormone in the body. ... parathyroid adenoma caused by the chronic overstimulation of hyperplastic ... osteopenia · brown tumors · salt and pepper sign in the skull (pepper pot skull)

questions.text: Reverse popeye sign is seen in
questions.solution: On examination, although there was no apparent bruising, the patient had an obvious “reverse Popeye's sign” showing a prominence in the proximal arm due to the proximal displacement of the biceps muscle belly, indicating rupture of the distal biceps tendon

choices.text: Recurrence is the most common complication following anterior dislocation
Bankarts lesion and hill sachs lesions are commonly seen in recurrent dislocation
Anterior defect in the humeral head is called hill sachs defect
Anterior inferior labral tear of the glenoid is called bankarts lesion

questions.text: Anterior shoulder dislocation, all are except....
questions.solution: Hill sachs defect is the defect in the postero superior part of the humeral head

questions.text: Fleck sign indicates..
questions.solution: Fleck sign indicates a small bony avulsion of the lisfranc ligament

questions.text: Thomas test is done for....
questions.solution: Test to correct lumbar lordosis that accompanies hip flexion deformity.

questions.text: Best Test used for early diagnosis and planning the treatment in suspected TB spine infection is...
questions.solution: Nucleic acid amplification assay (GeneXpert) is the most sensitive for early detection and also analysis of rifampin sensitivity.

choices.text: Ideal treatment is manipulation and casting
Posteromedial soft tissue release is the initial treatment of choice

questions.text: All are true regarding CTEV except...
questions.solution: PMSTR is done only when, manipulation and casting( Ponsetti) fails.

choices.text: Cafe au lait spots > 2 are diagnostic
Pseudoarthrosis tibia is seen in type 1 NF
Acoustic neuromas are seen in type 2 NF

questions.text: True regarding neurofibromatosis is all except:
questions.solution: Cafe au lait spots: > 6 measuring 1.5cm in adults and more than 0.5cm in children are diagnostic

questions.text: Codfish vertebra is seen in
questions.solution: 'Codfish vertebra' refers to the biconcave deformity of the vertebral body and is more common than anterior vertebral wedging and flat vertebra signs. It is not pathognomonic of postmenopausal osteoporosis and can be seen in other conditions and secondary causes of osteoporosis.

questions.text: Pseudoflexion deformity of hip is seen in...
questions.solution: TB spine patients can develop a psoas abscess. As it tracks down the inguinal canal it causes flexion deformity of the hip. As this deformity is not due hip pathology but due to spine pathology, it is called pseudo flexion deformity of the hip.

choices.text: May be a part of Multiple hereditary exostosis

questions.text: Madelung deformity, all are true except...
questions.solution: Its ulnopalmar subluxation of the wrist that spans across the distal radius growth plate and causes restricted growth.

questions.text: PIANO KEY sign is diagnostic of...
questions.solution:
The Piano-Key Sign Test is a test carried out for the clinical assessment of wrist instability. It is used as an indicator for distal radio-ulnar joint instability and tears of the triangular fibrocartilage complex of the wrist.

The piano-key test involves depressing the distal ulna from dorsal to volar with the hand pronated. A positive result is characterized by painful laxity in the affected wrist compared with the contralateral wrist. The results are usually positive in cases of DRUJ synovitis.

questions.text: Alpha angle in diagnostic USG screening of DDH
questions.solution: Alpha angle decreases and beta angle increases in USG in DDH

questions.text: Bowlers thumb....
questions.solution: Bowler's thumb refers to a rare, traumatic neuropathic condition involving the ulnar digital nerve of the thumb. The condition becomes symptomatic as the thumb undergoes chronic frictional irritation. It is induced when an avid bowler repeatedly compress the ulnar digital nerve by the thumbhole of a bowling ball.

questions.text: Most important tendon involved in tennis elbow:
questions.solution: Most commonly, the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) is involved, but others may include the extensor digitorum, extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL), and extensor carpi ulnaris.

questions.text: Clinical sign to diagnose deQuervains disease:
questions.solution: Cozens test is for tennis elbow

questions.text: Soap bubble appearance is seen in...
questions.solution: Giant cell tumours of bone tend to be lytic and expansile, being surrounded by a thin shell of bone, resulting in a 'soap bubble' appearance radiologically. They typically arise near the ends of long bones.

choices.text: Difference between Diastolic BP and compartment pressure < 30
Difference between Diastolic BP and compartment pressure > 30

questions.text: Ideal indication for fasciotomy
questions.solution:
Classic indications for prophylactic fasciotomy are prolonged limb ischemic time (more than 6 hours), a combined arterial and venous injury, and a massive soft tissue injury (i.e., crush).

If the compartment pressure is greater than 40 mm Hg, a fasciotomy is usually performed emergently, and fasciotomy is indicated if the pressure remains 30-40 mm Hg for longer than 4 hours. As a rule, when in doubt, the compartment should be released

questions.text: Ring sequestrum is seen in
questions.solution: Amputation stumps: crown sequestra, syphilis: black sequestra, TB: feathery/rice grain sequestra

questions.text: Patients presents with wrist pain, x ray showing a osteolytic area at the distal radius. Serum evaluation reveals increased Ca, Decreased Phosphate and elevated ALP. What's ur diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Elevated alkaline phosphatase in primary hyperparathyroidism

Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated in hyperparathyroidism. In primary hyperparathyroidism, levels may remain within the normal range, but this is inappropriately normal given the increased levels of plasma calcium

questions.text: IVDP at lumbar spine is MC at what level:
questions.solution: C6-C7 is most common level of IVDP in cervical spine

>5mm in adults, > 15mm in kids, > 5mm diameter
>5mm in adults, > 15mm in kids, > 6mm diameter
> 15mm in adults, >5mm in kids, > 6 mm diameter

questions.text: Dimensions of Cafe au lait spots required for the diagnosis of NF are?
questions.solution: Cafe au lait macules (CALM) are round to oval, tan to brown, flat, hairless lesions with distinct margins, ranging in size from a few millimeters to 15–20 cm in diameter, and can occur anywhere on the body

questions.text: Bohlers angle in intra-articular fractures of calcaneum.
questions.solution: Bohler's angle decreases in intra-articular fractures, Critical angle of gissane Increases

questions.text: Wagners technique of closed reduction is indicated in which of the following
questions.solution:
Bennett fracture closed reduction

Figure 2 Closed reduction of Bennett fractures is obtained by applying axial traction, palmar abduction, and pronation to the thumb metacarpal while providing pressure over the dorsal-radial metacarpal base. Recently, arthroscopic reduction and internal fixation of Bennett fractures was described.

choices.text: Diffuse alveolar involvement in fat embolism
Medial joint space widening in effusion of the hip
Collapse of the head in AVN femoral head

questions.text: Waldenstrom's sign indicates:
questions.solution:
Waldenström sign is the increased distance between the pelvic teardrop and the femoral head. It is a highly specific sign of a hip joint effusion.

  • >11 mm total distance or >2 mm difference compared to contralateral hip 1,2
  • measured between the lateral aspect of the pelvic teardrop and the medial aspect of the femoral head (referred to as Kohler teardrop distance) 1,2

choices.text: Excessive bone metabolism in hyperparathyroidism, resulting in osteolysis
Follows parathyroidectomy and indicates rebound hypercalcemia
Occurs after parathyroidectomy in a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism
Due to inadvertent removal of thyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy

questions.text: Hungry bone syndrome:
questions.solution: Hungry bone syndrome (HBS) refers to the rapid, profound, and prolonged hypocalcaemia associated with hypophosphataemia and hypomagnesaemia, and is exacerbated by suppressed parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, which follows parathyroidectomy in patients with severe primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) and preoperative high

questions.text: Aseptic loosening in THR is mainly due to
questions.solution: Aseptic loosening is due polyethylene debris due to wear and tear causing osteolysis

questions.text: Gorham's disease refers to.
questions.solution: Rare genetic disorder, characterized by lymphatic replacement of bone tissue, and idiopathic osteolysis

choices.text: Type II with Thurston Holland sign
Type III: epiphyseal + physeal + metaphyseal injury

questions.text: Worst type of physeal injury:
questions.solution: Type V Salter harris, is associated with crushing of the growth plate

questions.text: Traumatic Hip dislocations are best diagnosed using:
questions.solution: CT is the best modality for dislocations, also to see if it is associated with any fracture of the acetabulum or femoral head

questions.text: Ponsetti method of correcting clubfoot uses which joint as fulcrum for reduction:
questions.solution: Ponsetti method: TN joint, Kites method: Calcaneocuboid joint

choices.text: Distal femur fracture partially intra articular

questions.text: 33B fracture indicates....
questions.solution: AO classification. 33 means distal femur, B means partially intra-articular

questions.text: Piano key sign is positive in...
questions.solution: The piano-key test involves depressing the distal ulna from dorsal to volar with the hand pronated. A positive result is characterized by painful laxity in the affected wrist compared with the contralateral wrist. The results are usually positive in cases of DRUJ synovitis.

choices.text: Calcium levels are low normal or normal in primary hyperPTH
Calcium levels are low normal or normal in secondary hyperPTH
Low Phosphate levels are only seen in secondary hyperPTH
High phosphate levels in primary hyperPTH

questions.text: Differentiating feature between primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism:

Calcium: high

PTH: Very high

Secondary hyperPTH:

Calcium: Low normal or normal

PTH: high

Phosphate levels are low both in primary and secondary hyperPTH.

choices.text: Compression of communication between medial and lateral plantar nerve

questions.text: Most common cause for neuralgic pain in the foot is
questions.solution:
Compression of communication

  • Absence or collapse of the arches leads to flat foot or pes planus. The loss of concavity of sole leads to compression of nerves and vessels of sole resulting in neurologic pain in foot.

questions.text: Arthroscopy is contraindicated in
questions.solution: Bleeding into joints is common in hemophilia. Treatment is with ice packs/compression and factor VIII replacement/AVP. Aspiration will lead to recurrent hemarthosis due to loss of tamponade effect.

questions.text: Most common organism responsible for Acute haematogenous osteomyelitis is
questions.solution:
Pathophysiology. The most common type of osteomyelitis, an infection of bone, that occurs in children is acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. Infection initially is established in the metaphyseal region of tubular bones, beginning as a metaphysitis following seeding by bacteria

Acute hematogenous osteomyelitis usually occurs after an episode of bacteremia in which the organisms inoculate the bone. The organisms most commonly isolated in these cases include S aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenza type b (less common since the use of vaccine for H influenza type b

questions.text: Caffey's disease is
questions.solution: Caffey disease, also called infantile cortical hyperostosis, is a bone disorder that most often occurs in babies. Excessive new bone formation (hyperostosis) is characteristic of Caffey disease

questions.text: Non-healing sinus is a common clinical feature in chronic osteomyelitis. The most common frequent cause for this presentation is
questions.solution:
• Chronic osteomyelitis represents a progressive inflammatory process caused by pathogens, resulting in bone destruction and sequestrum formation.
  • It may present with periods of quiescence of variable duration, whereas its occurrence, type, severity and prognosis is multifactorial.
  • The ‘gold standard’ for the diagnosis of chronic osteomyelitis is the presence of positive bone cultures and histopathologic examination of the bone.

It can reveal soft tissue swelling, periosteal reaction, loss of definition, loss of bone density and osteolysis, as early as 10 to 21 days after the bone infection, but may not be detectable until there is a loss of 30% to 50% of the bone mineral content.2.9.12.20 Late signs include increased bone resorption, formation of sequestra and new bone formation in the periosteum or endosteum.20

questions.text: Ankylosing Spondylitis is associated with
questions.solution: HLA-B27 is found in 88% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis. It is inherited in a Mendelian fashion, and it is found in 50% of first-degree relatives of those patients with spondyloarthropathies who are HLA-B27 positive. The chance that an HLA-B27 patient will develop spondyloarthritis or eye disease is 1 in 4

choices.text: Septic arthritis of hip joint in infants

questions.text: Tom Smith arthritis is
questions.solution: It's a sequalae of septic arthritis in infants.
